title: Doctor who groped nurse blames 'euphoric' reaction to pet spray he uses to calm his dogs during thunderstorms
text:
A doctor groped a female colleague because he suffered a "euphoric" reaction to a pet calming spray, a tribunal heard today.

Dr Colin Gelder, 59, claimed he squeezed the nurse's bottom on a hospital ward after fumes from the solution he uses to calm his dogs during thunderstorms adversely reacted with his hayfever medication.

The married father-of-two said he "felt like superman" when he accosted the 55-year-old at University Hospital in Coventry, West Midlands, at 9am on September 1, 2017.

A medical tribunal in Manchester heard that the woman later told him the only person allowed to touch her bottom was her husband, to which Gelder replied: "Well, he's a very lucky man."

Dr Gelder also told another female colleague, 60, during the same shift "you're sexy when you are cross" when she reprimanded him for not assessing patients properly.

The consultant respiratory physician, who has been practising medicine for 35 years, admitted the incidents involving the two women and now faces being struck off.

But he blamed his "out of character" behaviour on the herb Valerian used in Pet Remedy products and insisted his actions were not sexually motivated.

"It remains my mitigation that this wholly bizarre behaviour is explained by my exposure to the product," Dr Gelder told the tribunal.
description: A doctor groped a female colleague because he suffered a "euphoric" reaction to a pet calming spray, a tribunal heard today.
